header.title: The Scroll of Set (Issue Number 80, Volume XI-6, October 1985)

central_thesis: This issue of The Scroll of Set offers a critical Setian perspective on contemporary occultism, particularly as depicted in the documentary 'The Occult Experience'. It champions a philosophy of magic rooted in subjective experience and rigorous self-individuation, contrasting this with performative or exoteric approaches to ritual, and engages in a philosophical discourse on the nature of 'objective' versus 'subjective' reality as it pertains to magical practice.

structure_content.chapter_title: Commentary: The Occult Experience by Michael A. Aquino VI°
structure_content.summary: A detailed critical review of the documentary 'The Occult Experience', assessing its technical merits (photography, narration, soundtrack) and its portrayal of various occult groups. Aquino argues that most groups appeared 'adolescent and comic' due to staging and performance for the camera, which he deems a 'profaning' of sacred ritual. He highlights the Temple of Set's refusal to stage a ritual, emphasizing that true ritual magic is a subjective experience, not a show. He concludes that the film inadvertently validates the Temple of Set's high opinion of its own quality by showcasing the superficiality of much Western occultism.

structure_content.chapter_title: Alien Visions by Mitchell E. Wade I°
structure_content.summary: An appreciation and analysis of H.R. Giger's art, especially in the context of 'The Occult Experience' film. Wade describes Giger's work as 'the darkest visions yet to be brought into being', associating it with the 'Old Ones', the 'Klippothic' aspect of the Tree of Life, and the Norse underworld goddess 'Hel'. He posits that Giger's 'biomechanical' art provides almost photographic illustrations of concepts central to Setian invocation, such as 'Enfold me with the Powers of Darkness' and 'I am lord of Life, Death, and Life in Death'.

A philosophical discussion expanding on Adept Ogle's previous letter regarding 'objective experience' and 'truth'. Flowers critiques the notion of 'objective' knowledge by drawing on historical philosophers (Locke, Berkeley) and modern psychology (Carl Jung, neuro-linguistics). She argues that human perception constructs a 'neurological model of reality', not reality itself, and that sensory organs vary, leading to individual differences in perception. This leads to the conclusion that 'objective' knowledge of 'objective' reality is specious, supporting a subjective framework for magical experience.

A short, evocative poem celebrating the annual Setian Conclave, set against the backdrop of 'All Hallows Eve' in a desert landscape. It speaks of the 'chosen, the few among many' gathering around a cloaked figure at 'Xa'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Working After-Thoughts by Robert Robinson I°
structure_content.summary: A poetic reflection on an internal magical 'Working', describing a deep, personal transformation and merging with an 'unknown' or 'him who waits'. It emphasizes overcoming 'twisted truths' and 'chains of guilt' to gain 'wisdom that terminates the fall', ultimately leading to the 'possession of the self' and understanding the 'meaning of Set' for 'great happiness'.

key_concepts.definition: A profound, internal action or ritual that should not be profaned by staging or performance for external observers, contrasted with conventional religious pageantry or showmanship.

The primary nature of ritual magic and individual perception of reality, where personal internal apprehension and transformation are paramount, rather than external, observable phenomena or 'objective data'. This is central to Setian practice and understanding of reality.

Challenged as a misnomer, it refers to 'information whose direct origin is from the interplay of the central nervous system with objective data'. Philosophical arguments (Locke, Berkeley) and psychological models suggest that humans perceive a 'neurological model of reality' rather than objective reality itself, rendering the concept problematic.

A core Setian goal, articulated as 'Be only self! Seek only self! Seek possession of the self only, and all other possessions follow.' It implies radical individualism and the cultivation of one's unique being as the source of power and happiness.

Described as the 'obverse aspect of the integrative energies of the Cabalistic Tree of Life', used to contextualize the dark and unsettling nature of H.R. Giger's art, aligning it with underworld or shadow realms.

A term used in Setian invocation, referenced in the context of H.R. Giger's art as 'almost photographic illustrations' of concepts like 'Enfold me with the Powers of Darkness; let them become one with me...'

practical_system.description: The text implicitly outlines a magical system focused on radical self-individuation, subjective experience, and inner transformation, rather than external theatrics or 'showmanship'. Setian magic ('Workings') is portrayed as a sacred, deeply personal, and internal process aimed at achieving 'self-possession' and a unique godhood. It emphasizes a deep understanding of one's own subjective reality and the cultivation of individual will and being. The system rejects the need for external validation or performative display, viewing such actions as profaning the true magical experience.
tools: Understanding of subjective reality and rejection of 'objective' knowledge as specious
Art (e.g., Giger's work for inspiration/illustration of concepts)
rituals: Internal 'Workings' focused on self-transformation and the cultivation of individual will, rather than externally staged or performative acts.
Invocation (implied via Giger's art representing 'Powers of Darkness' concepts).
Personal engagement with the 'unknown' and the 'Beast' for wisdom and self-realization.

relevant_quotes.text: ritual magic, by its very nature, is a subjective experience rather than a show put on to impress onlookers (as is conventional religious pageantry).
But such staging, no matter how well intentioned, inevitably strikes me as a profaning of an action that should itself be regarded as a sacred experience.

Be only self! Seek only self! Seek possession of the self only, and all other possessions follow. Be alone, and in your aloofness know the love and respect of others who sense the source of your power.

Defining “objective experience" as "information whose direct origin is from the interplay of the central nervous system with objective data" could certainly cause misapprehension of the concepts “subjective” and "objective".
We do not perceive reality, but rather a neurological model of reality. And because sensory organs vary greatly from one individual to another, each one of us perceives the world differently.

It is my opinion that Giger provides almost photographic illustrations of the concepts embodied in these words ["Enfold me with the Powers of Darkness; let them become one with me ..." - and - "I am lord of Life, Death, and Life in Death."]

critical_analysis.relevance: This text provides a significant insight into the Temple of Set's self-conception and its critical engagement with the broader occult community in the mid-1980s. It differentiates Setian philosophy from other traditions by emphasizing the internal, subjective, and non-performative nature of magic and self-transformation. The philosophical discussion on subjective/objective reality grounds Setian practice in a unique epistemological framework, making it relevant for understanding modern esotericism's intellectual debates. It serves as both internal instruction and external delineation for the Temple of Set.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Primarily members and initiates of the Temple of Set, providing internal commentary on current events, philosophical discourse, and reaffirming core Setian tenets. Secondarily, it is relevant for academics and practitioners interested in the history, philosophy, and practical distinctions within modern Western occultism, particularly regarding Left-Hand Path traditions and their critiques of mainstream occult practices.
